newsitem.title: INDONESIA: Withdrawal of Indonesian editor's licence slammed.
newsitem.headline: Withdrawal of Indonesian editor's licence slammed.

text.p: Indonesia's Alliance of Independent Journalists (AJI) said on Thursday the country's official journalists' union was helping authorities restrict media freedom by withdrawing a magazine editor's licence.

The government-backed Indonesian Journalists' Association (PWI) said on Wednesday it had withdrawn the editing licence of Goesti Emran, editor-in-chief of the weekly Detektip & Romantiak (D&R) magazine, because he employed members of the unrecognised AJI.
The removal of the licence could lead to the magazine closing down, because under Indonesia's strict press laws such official approval is needed for before a publication can go to print.
"We are critical of the actions of a journalists' organisation which constricts the creative opportunities for all journalists," Santoso, head of the AJI presidium, said in a statement.

"Moreover, it puts that journalists' organisation in a position which is subordinated to authority. Humiliatingly, (the PWI) has let itself become an instrument for the restriction of the freedom of the press in our country."
On Thursday, AJI members went to the official National Commission on Human Rights to complain about the PWI decision.
AJI was formed in reaction to the banning of three outspoken weekly publications -- Tempo, Editor and DeTik -- by the government in June 1994.
A number of its members have been removed from their jobs since its formation in what media watchers say is a result of government pressure on editors.
Three people associated with a former publication of AJI were jailed last year for spreading hatred against the president.
